bibl.title: Article: Vindicating Finlay's Glory, by Jorge LeRoy y Cassa, February 1927

div1.p: LeRoy y Cassa defends Finlay against the claims of the Rockefeller Foundation and others. He refers to Marie Gorgas and Burton J. Hendrick's biography of William Crawford Gorgas.

div1.head: Article: Vindicating Finlay's Glory, by Jorge LeRoy y Cassa, February 1927
div1.p: Translated from the Spanish, HRM
LeRoy y Cassa, Dr. Jorge

Reivindicacion de la gloria de Finlay, Sanidad y
Beneficencia, Boletin Oficial, Havana, February and March,
1927, v.32, p. 204-215.

The reputation of great men is in a position similar to that of
precious articles exhibited in museums. In some people these articles arouse
sentiments of admiration and appreciation for the craftsmen who made them and
for their fortunate possessors; in others they arouse a desire to steal and to
possess them, regardless of the method used to achieve this end.

It is, indeed, a pity that one should find it necessary to become a
guardian of the glory of the benefactors of humanity in order to prevent
usurpation of this glory by those who, having forgotten the commandment, “Thou
shalt not steal” (Exodus, Chap. XX, Verse 15), in the Old Testament which Moses
promulgated to the Hebrew people on descending from the summits of Sinai, stamp
out historic truth and attribute to definite persons deeds that, were they alive,
they would be the first indignantly to reject. Their honesty, their probity,
their straightforward and patriotic judgment would not allow them to accept what
others attribute to them, even though it cover them with the glorious splendors
of discoveries foisted upon them by unscrupulous organizations who thus exemplify
a well-known Spanish proverb to the effect that a foreigner is always fair prey
to the mob.

The foregoing remarks were suggested to me by the firm in-
sistence with which the Rockefeller Foundation has for years attributed
to Reed and to the Commission appointed by the American Government,
over which he presided (1900-1901), the discovery of the method of
transmission of yellow fever. This opinion is also upheld in the book
which has recently been published: William Crawford Gorgas--His Life
and Works, by Marie D. Gorgas and Burton J. Hendrick; in an editorial,
“Yellow Fever Withdraws from the Americas”, published by the Journal
of the American Medical Association, Spanish edition, November 15, 1926,
V. 16, p. 676, which reproduces almost ad pedem literae the section by
Dr. George E. Vincent, President of the Rockefeller Foundation, in the
“Compte-Rendu de l'Oeuvre Accomplie en 1925”, New York, 1926, p. 16-19.

The above article contains so many categorical and unjust
statements that it is impossible to note them without making the neces-
sary corrections, such as: “Twenty-five years ago, the United States
Commission, headed by Walter Reed, discovered in Havana the method of trans-
mission (of yellow fever)”; “The yellow fever patient may infect the
mosquito only on the first day of his disease”; “Now that the microbe
that produces the fever is isolated, there are methods available for the
diagnosis and possibly for immunity”.

Were we not dealing with a publication of the importance and
seriousness which characterizes the Journal of the American Medical
Association and, above all, of the Spanish edition of this journal, which
is read in all Central and South American countries and by other Spanish
speaking people on the continent of Europe, we would have overlooked,
-3-
perhaps, these incorrect statements and this evident distortion of the
historical truth. But since these remarks appeared in the nature of an
editorial in such an important publication it is impossible to notice
them without registering our protest, especially in view of the remarks
made by Dr. Mario G. Lebredo at a solemn occasion (Feb. 6, 1926, on the
unveiling of the bust of Finlay in the Academy of Medical Sciences):
“......only a few direct spokesmen of his fame are left; only a few of
us who lived at the time of his campaign remain to impose his ideals,
and the era is now beginning in which one has to search the literature
to appreciate those moments when all scientific and applied speculation
had to be derived from the principles of his doctrine. And, unfortunately,
it is still necessary to make this point clear, for we still have to re-
fer to his far-reaching fundamental and determining part in the magnifi-
cent success in the eradication of yellow fever in order to correct
the misinterpretation of the historical facts which tend to place his
figure on a secondary plans.” (Annals of the Academy of Medical, Physical
and Natural Sciences of Havana, V. 62, p. 498; Bulletin of the Board of
National Hygiene, Montevideo, 1926, p. 5-6 of the tribute to the memory
of Dr. Carlos J. Finlay.)

Since I, fortunately, am one of the few survivors of that
period in which Finlay worked with his faithful friend and constant
collaborator, Dr. Claudio Delgado; since I witnessed the immortal work
of the Commission of Medical Officers appointed by the Government of the
United States, presided over by Reed, and which included Carroll, Lazear
-4-
and our Agramonte, whom they also apparently would like to eliminate;
since I collaborated with Finlay, Gorgas, Guiteras, Diaz Albertini, as
Secretary of the Yellow Fever Commission precisely at the moment when
Gorgas, by applying Finlay's doctrines which were demonstrated by the
Commission, succeeded in completely eradicating yellow fever from our
land; since it is not the first time that I have had to clarify this
same subject, for in this Academy in the month of January and then in
number 3 of February, 1924, I was compelled to use the columns of this
very same Journal of the American Medical Association to refute similar
beliefs, I now find it absolutely necessary to discuss once more this
vexatious subject, for when the date to which Dr. Lebredo referred to
comes, and it becomes necessary to search the literature for the appre-
ciation of those moments, there shall be found together with the pub-
lished errors the necessary corrections and the protest of those of us
who have a right to do so, for we were his witnesses. It is our duty
to do this as men of science who cannot allow the distortion of the
truth of the historical facts.

We are to make use only of first-hand information, as given
by those who actually took part in the work, and we shall limit ourselves
in presenting their writings at the very moment in which a doctrine an-
nounced twenty years earlier was being confirmed and not discovered. The
Commission, by means of admirable and accurate experiments, demonstrated
the doctrine and divulged it to the medical world in order that it may
later be studied and confirmed in the various countries which were studying
this important subject, since the black vomit was one of the greatest
-5-
menaces and one of the greatest difficulties to the habitation of the
tropics.
Let us now examine the facts.

First statement: “Twenty-five years ago the United States
Commission headed by Walter Reed, discovered in Havana the method of
transmission.”

In Protocol No. 7, page 34, of the International Sanitary
Conference held in Washington, D. C., and at the session of February 18,
1881, Dr. Carlos J. Finlay, delegate of Cuba and Porto Rico, made the
following remarks:

"My personal opinion is that three conditions are, in fact,
necessary for the propagation of yellow fever:

"First - The presence of a previous case of yellow fever,
within certain limits of time, counting from the moment we are considering.
"Second - The presence of a person apt to contract the disease.

“Third - The presence of an agent entirely independent for
its existence both of the disease and of the patient, but which is
necessary in order that the disease shall be conveyed from the yellow
fever patient to a healthy individual.”

Finlay made these remarks in Washington, that is, in the
United States, at an International Sanitary Conference; and they serve
to answer the objection that Finlay wrote only in Cuba and for Cubans.
As yet he does not state what is the intermediate agent between the sick
and the non-immune; but a few months later, at the session of August 14,
1881, (and not in 1880, as is erroneously stated in the Report of
-6-
General Wood) before the Royal Academy of Medical, Physical and Natural
Sciences of Havana (Anales de la Real Academia De Ciencias Medicas,
Fisicas y Naturales de la Habana, V. 18, pa. 147-169) he read a study
entitled, “The Mosquito Hypothetically Considered As Agent of Trans-
mission of Yellow Fever”, and his conclusions are as follows:

“Three conditions will, therefore, be necessary in order that
yellow fever may be propagated: First, the existence of a yellow fever
patient into whose capillaries the mosquito is able to drive its sting
and to impregnate it with the virulent particles at an appropriate stage
of the disease; second, that the life of the mosquito be spared after
its bite upon the patient until it has a chance of biting the person in
whom the disease is to be reproduced; third, the coincidence that some
of the persons whom the same mosquito happens to bite thereafter shall
be susceptible of contracting the disease.”

In conclusion number 4 of this same study there is found a
statement wherein with characteristic clearness Finlay foresees the
successes that were to be demonstrated and even proved twenty years
later by the American Commission and by the other Commissions which con-
firmed the importance of the culcidae doctrine of yellow fever. He
states as follows:

“Should it be finally proved that the mosquito inoculation
not only reproduces the yellow fever, but that it constitutes the
regular process through which the disease is propagated, the conditions
of existence and of development for that dipterous insect would account
for the anomalies hitherto observed in the propagation of yellow fever,
and while we might, on the one hand, have the means of preventing the
disease from spreading, non-immunes might at the same time be protected
through a mild inoculation”.

But there are still other statements of Finlay to be mentioned
in order to show that long before the Commission was appointed which
authentically proved his doctrines, he had already revealed in great
details the transmission of yellow fever. The first statement was made
in January, 1884, at the meeting of the Society of Clinical Studies of
-7-
Havana held from January 31 to February 29. On this occasion he read
another study on the “experimental yellow fever compared with the natural
in its benign forms,” and “experimental yellow fever inoculated by means
of bites of mosquitoes” which he published, revised and annotated in the
ARCHIVOS DE LA SOCIEDAD DE ESTUDIOS CLINICOS DE LA HABANA (1903, V. 12,
p. 281-332). In the latter study he states as follows:

“The fact that yellow fever can be inoculated by the bites
of mosquitoes proves the necessity of protecting the patients infected
with disease against such bites in order to prevent the propagation of
the disease.”

This conclusion, the fundamental principle on which the
prophylaxis of yellow fever rests at the present time, is all the more
interesting because it was formulated at the beginning of 1884, and
represents the synthesis of the work read in the same Academy towards
the end of 1898 (November 13) wherein he reveals the fundamental basis
which Gorgas in 1901 used for the eradication of this terrible endemic
from our country which had constantly been devastating our capital since
1761. Finlay concludes that study by stating that:

“In accordance with the theories on mosquitoes, in order to
free the Island of Cuba from two of the most terrible scourges which have
ravaged the land (yellow fever and malaria) it will be necessary, then, to
declare a constant war against the mosquito and to surround each yellow
fever or malaria patient with all the imaginable precautions to prevent
that these insects become infected by the ill or by their infectious
products.” “The mosquitoes considered as agents of transmission of yellow
fever and malaria”, published in English under title: “Mosquitoes Con-
sidered As Transmitters of Yellow Fever and Malaria” in the NEW YORK
-8-
MEDICAL RECORD, New York, 1899, (V. 45, p. 737-739, May 27).

Up to this point we have been considering Finlay. Let us now
examine in chronological order the facts as recorded by the American Com-
mission. Professor Sanarelli had announced his discovery that the
specific cause of the vomit was the icteroides bacillus and for this
purpose Dr. George Sternberg who at that time held the position of Sur-
geon General of the United States and who had come as Secretary of the
First Commission appointed by that country in 1879, presided over by
Professor Chaille, in turn appointed a Commission presided over by Dr.
Walter Reed, and composed of Drs. James Carroll, Aristides Agramonte and
Jesse W. Lazear, created “for the study of acute infectious diseases of
the Island of Cuba”. This is what they themselves state in the preliminary
note published on October 27, 1900, in the PHILADELPHIA MEDICAL JOURNAL
and translated by Dr. Guiteras for his REVISTA DE MEDICINA TROPICAL (Havana,
October, 1900, V. 1, p. 49-64). This work was read before the American
Public Health Association, at its 28th meeting, in Indianapolis, United
States of America.

In this study Dr. Reed and his associates made the following
statement:

“The Mosquito as host of the yellow fever parasite. Having
failed to isolate B. icteroides, either from the blood during life, or
from the organs of cadavers, two courses of procedure in our further in-
vestigations appeared to be deserving of attention, viz., first, a careful
study of the intestinal flora in yellow fever in comparison with the bac-
teria that we might isolate from the intestinal canal of healthy individuals,
-9-
in this vicinity, or of those sick with other diseases; and secondly, to
give our attention to the theory of the propagation of yellow fever by
means of the mosquito--a theory first advanced and ingeniously discussed
by Dr. Carlos J. Finlay, of Havana, in 1881 (Anales de la Real Academia,
V. 18, 1881, pp. 147-169.) We were influenced to take up the second line
of investigation by reason of the well-known facts connected with the
epidemiology of this disease, and, of course, by the brilliant work of
Ross and the Italian observers, in connection with the theory of the
propagation of malaria by the mosquito.”
And a little further on they add:

“In view of the foregoing observations (referring to Carter's
investigations) we concluded to test the theory of Finlay on human beings.
According to this author's observations of numerous inoculations in 90
individuals, the application of one or two contaminated mosquitoes is not
dangerous, but followed in about 18%, by an attack of what he considers
to be a very benign yellow fever at most.” “We here desire to express our
sincere thanks to Dr. Finlay, who accorded us a most courteous interview
and has gladly placed at our disposal his several publications relating to
yellow fever, during the past 19 years; and also for ova of the species of
mosquito with which he had made his several inoculations. An important ob-
servation to be recorded here is that, according to Finlay's statement,
30 days prior to our visit, these ova had been deposited by a female just
at the edge of the water in a small basin, whose contents had been allowed
to slightly evaporate, so that these ova were at the time of our visit
entirely above contact with the water. Notwithstanding this long interval
-10-
after deposition, they were promptly converted into the larval stage,
after a short period, by raising the level of the water in the basin.”

“With the mosquitoes thus obtained we have been able to con-
duct our experiments. Specimens of this mosquito forwarded to Mr. L. A.
Howard, Entomologist, Department of Agriculture, Washington, D. C., were
kindly identified as Culex Fasciatus, Fabr.”

“In this preliminary note we have no space to refer, at length,
to the various interesting and valuable contributions made by Finlay to
the mosquito theory for the propagation of yellow fever......”

The above remarks were written by the Commission presided over
by Reed and made public in Indianapolis, United States, in nothing less
than at a meeting of the American Public Health Association, the most
notable authority in questions of public hygiene in that great country.

The conclusions arrived at by the members of the Commission,
published in that Preliminary Note were: with reference to the first
part of its study that:

“The Bacillus icteroides (Sanarelli) stands in no causative
relation to yellow fever, but, when present, it should be considered as
a secondary invader on this disease.”

“Of the second part of our study of yellow fever we draw the
following conclusion: the mosquito serves as the intermediate host for
the parasite of yellow fever and it is very probable that the disease
is only propagated by the bite of this insect.”

At the Third Pan American Medical Congress held in Havana
from February 4 to 8, 1901, Drs. Reed, Carroll and Agramonte, for poor
-11-
Lazear had sacrificed his life in the holocaust of science and died as
a result of yellow fever which had been inoculated by the mosquitoes in
the Field of Experimentation,--the latter has since been named in his honor--
read an Additional Note to the one presented in Indianapolis during the
previous year in which they revealed all the work, observations and ex-
periments which will make the names of said members of the commissions
immortal, for science and humanity owes them the greatest debt of gratitude
of our times.

Up to the present we have seen that Reed and his associates
of the Commission recognize Finlay as the discoverer of the theory that
yellow fever is transmitted by the mosquito. Let us now see whatexamine Gorgas,
the great organizer of the public health of Cuba, the good, just, modest,
uncensurable man who collaborated with Finlay and who was fortunate enough to
witness the eradication of yellow fever--by the application of the doctrines
of this learned man--first from Cuba, then from Panama, and who later con-
tinued his fight against the yellow monster into the heart of Africa,
which he was unable to reach on account of his death in London on his way
to investigate the existence of this disease in the African continent
and, if present, to eradicate it.

“Towards the middle of February of the current year we based
our campaign against yellow fever on the supposition that the mosquito is
the method by which the disease is transmitted from one person to another.
- 12 -
This theory which was originally presented by Dr. Carlos Finlay of Havana
has finally been confirmed by the beautiful and complete experiments made
by the Yellow Fever Commission presided over by Commander Walter Reed.”

“When the results of these experiments became known, the Military
Governor, General Leonard Wood, ordered that great efforts be made to dis-
infect the areas in accordance with the indications of this discovery. The
results of the work accomplished during the last four months have strength-
ened the conclusions arrived at by the Commission.” REPORT OF THE COMMANDER
W. C. GORGAS, Havana, July 8, 1901 (p. 98).

On November 5, of the same year (1901) and in the same source of
information (p. 210) Gorgas wrote as follows:

“I insist most emphatically on the records of yellow fever in our
sanitary statistics, because of its considerable practical importance for
the United States, and because it has definitely been assured that yellow
fever is transmitted by the “Stegomyia” mosquito, a fact upheld by Dr.
Carlos Finlay as against the ridiculous theory which has prevailed for so
many years. Finlay's theory has recently been demonstrated by the com-
mission of army officers, and will soon change our methods of quarantine
in the United States.”

“The theory that the mosquito is the only method of spreading the
disease is responsible for the success of our work in Havana this year.
Since we have not considered it necessary to disinfect the clothing and
other contaminable substances, we have concentrated our efforts in killing
the mosquitoes which may have bitten the patient and in preventing other
mosquitoes from doing likewise. Our results in accordance with this plan
- 13 -
have been so positive that we soon saw not only the possibility of freeing
Havana from yellow fever but also of destroying all the foci of infection
imported from the exterior.”

In the “Vital Statistics Report of the Cities of Havana and
Guanabacia, submitted to the Brigadier General Leonard Wood, U.S.A.,
Military Governor, in January, 1902, Gorgas himself wrote:

“In the summer of 1900 a commission of Army medical officers
headed by Major Walter Reed, U.S. Army, had been sent to Cuba for the
investigation and study of yellow fever. Due to the financial assistance
given by the Military Governor to this Commission, they were enabled to
experiment on the human subject. They based their work on the theory ad-
vanced by Dr. Carlos Finlay, of Havana, in the year 1880, (it was in the
year 1881) that the Stegomyia mosquito was the sole means of the trans-
mission of yellow fever. Dr. Finlay had maintained this theory for some
twenty years, and had done considerable experimental work in this direc-
tion.”

“The Commission through elaborate and careful experimentation,
proved this theory to be correct, and in February, 1901, Doctor Reed read
a paper before the International Sanitary Congress, in Havana, (it was the
third Pan American Medical Congress) giving the results of their work.
This idea was so new and so entirely contrary to all former theories on
the subject, and, apparently, to all former experience, that the paper was
received with scant belief. I myself had seen the experiments, and was
convinced that the mosquito could convey yellow fever, but I could not
accept the theory that it was the only way, or even the ordinary way, of
conveying the disease.”

Finally, Gorgas himself in his last REPORT written in the
General Quarters of the Department of Cuba, Prefecture of the Department
of Public Health, and dated Havana, July 12, 1902, addressed to the Briga-
dier General Leonard Wood, Army of the United States, Washington, D.C.,
states as follows:

“General: I herewith forward the report of the sanitary department,
bringing the account of the work up to May 20, of the present year.”

“This being the final report of the sanitary department of the
City of Havana, under the Military Government, it might be useful to review,
in a general way, the work of the department since its inception in 1899.”

“The great object of sanitation for Cuba, and particularly for
Havana, as far as the United States was concerned, was the eradication of
yellow fever.”

He discusses at great length the conditions in which they found
the island and especially Havana; the dangers to which the country was sub-
ject as a result of the infected neighborhood. He reproduces integrally
the paragraphs which I have just transcribed from the Report issued in
January, 1902, and he also describes the work carried out from February 4,
1901, for combating yellow fever which caused him to change his opinion,
and fully convinced he then says:

“But there is no doubt that the most important sanitary lesson
with regard to yellow fever is that the disease is only conveyed by the
Stegomyia mosquito; that the disease can readily be eradicated, even when
it has gotten a firm hold, and easily kept from establishing itself by
taking measures looking for the mosquito as its cause.” (p. 8).

Up to this point we have been examining in a clear and precise
manner the statements made by Reed and his associates of the Commission,
and the remarks and statements made by Gorgas on various occasions. Let
us now see the statements made in a solemn and formal manner by General
Wood, who was not only the Military Governor of Cuba, but also a physician.
This enabled him to personally appreciate not merely by reference, the
truth of the facts which he himself describes in the REPORT OF THE BRIGADIER
GENERAL LEONARD WOOD, U. S. A., MILITARY GOVERNOR OF CUBA for the period
January 1 to May 20, 1902 (pages 172-174).

"Affairs were in this condition when a systematic investigation
of yellow fever was undertaken by Drs. Reed, Carroll and Lazear (where does
he leave Agramonte?). These officers took up the work in a very thorough
and conscientious manner, starting at the point previously reached by
Dr. Finlay.

“They accepted Dr. Finlay's idea that yellow fever was transmitted
by a mosquito. After several preliminary investigations, Dr. Lazear sub-
mitted himself voluntarily as a subject for an experiment for the purpose
of demonstrating that the yellow fever could be transmitted in this way.
He was inoculated by an infected mosquito, took the fever and died.
Dr. Carroll was also bitten by a mosquito and had a rather serious case
of yellow fever, but, fortunately, recovered....”

He then discusses the financial assistance given to the Commission
for its experimental investigations and the conditions required by them, and
continues as follows:

“The Stegomyia mosquito was found to be beyond question the means
of transmitting yellow fever. This mosquito, in order to become infected,
- 16 -
must bite a person sick with the yellow fever during the first five days
of the disease. It then requires approximately ten days for the germ to
so develop that the mosquito can transmit the disease, and all non-immunes
who are bitten by a mosquito of the class mentioned, infected as described,
invariably develop a pronounced cases of yellow fever in from three and a
half to five days from the time they are bitten. It was further demon-
strated that infection from cases so produced could be again transmitted
by the above described type of mosquito to another person who would, in
turn, have yellow fever. It was also proved that yellow fever could be
transmitted by means of introduction of blood or blood serum, even after
filtering through porcelain filters, which latter experiment indicates
that the organism is exceedingly small, - so small, in fact, that it is
probably beyond the power of any microscope at present in use. It was
positively demonstrated that yellow fever could not be transmitted by
clothing, contact, etc., and that, consequently, all the old methods of
fumigation and disinfection were only useful in so far as they served to
destroy mosquitoes, their young and their eggs.”

“With the establishment of these facts, there was inaugurated an
entirely new method of dealing with yellow fever, - a method very similar
to that adopted in the treatment of malaria fever, with the only difference
that it is carried out much more thoroughly (p. 174).”

We have limited ourselves in quoting those authorities who took
a direct and immediate part in the demonstration and confirmation of the
doctrines which Finlay upheld as early as February, 1881, in Washington,
because no one is better qualified to testify to the truth; that is, that
Finlay before anybody else discovered the method of transmission of yellow
- 17 -
fever from the patient to the healthy, and that this method was the
mosquito. Where is, then, the solemn affirmation made by the Rockefeller
Foundation of the DISCOVERY of Reed, if he himself states the truth, which
is contrary to that false statement? This fact simply and clearly con-
stitutes an usurpation and what has been said above serves to confirm it
in a categorical manner.

Second affirmation: “The yellow fever patient may infect the mosquito
only during the first day of his sickness.”
Let us see what Finlay says.

In the conclusions of the second part “experimental yellow fever
inoculated by means of bites from mosquito” of the work “experimental yellow
fever compared with the natural in its benign forms” dated 1884 (TRABAJOS
SELECTOS DEL DR. CARLOS J. FINLAY, Havana, 1912, p. 103) he states as
follows:

"1. Yellow fever is regularly inoculated on the third, fourth, fifth
and sixth days of its usual development by means of the bite of the diurnal
mosquito of Havana (Culex Mosquito-Robineau Desvoidy) and in a footnote of
the page in the revised and annotated work by the author and published in
the above source it states: “In my recent investigations I have noted that
the only condition for infecting the mosquitoes is that the disease should
not develop beyond the fifth or sixth day. The French Commission of Brazil
(1901-1903) has demonstrated that the fever is not communicated by injecting
blood of the fourth nor of the eighth day.”

“2. The above disease may be transmitted by the above mentioned method
during the first days and after the sixth day of its evolution, regardless
of the intensity of the symptoms present in this latter period.”

In its turn, the Commission presided over by Reed and which was
then composed by J. Carroll and A. Agramonte in its Additional Note called
“The etiology of yellow fever” presented to the Third Pan American Medical
Congress held in Havana in February, 1901, contains the following conclu-
sion dealing with our present study:

"2. Yellow fever is transmitted to the nonimmune individual by means
of the bite of the mosquito that has previously fed on the blood of those
sick with this disease.

"3. It appears that an interval of twelve or more days, after contam-
ination appears to be necessary before the mosquito is capable of conveying
the infection.

"4. The bite of the mosquito at an earlier period than that mentioned
in the preceding paragraph does not appear to confer any immunity against
a subsequent attack of yellow fever.

“5. Yellow fever can also be experimentally produced by the subcutan-
eous injection of blood taken from the general circulation during the first
and second days of this attack.”

During the period that has elapsed since Finlay wrote his study
in 1884 and that in which the Commission submitted its report in 1900-1901,
the distinguished investigators who have studied this subject have not
differed in anyway from what those authors had expressed; therefore it is
to be supposed that a gross error has been made by the author of the edi-
torial on which we are commenting when he states that “the yellow fever
patient may infect the mosquito only on the first day of his disease”.

We now come to the third and last of the statements of the above
mentioned writer: “Now that the microbe of the fever has been isolated,
there are methods available for the diagnosis and possibly for immunity.”

A special article has just been published in No. 51 of volume 41
of the PUBLIC HEALTH REPORTS issued weekly by the United States Public Health
Service entitled: “The Control of Communicable Diseases” containing the
report issued by the Committee on Standard Regulations to which the various
sanitary services must be subjected. This report was prepared by the Ameri-
can Public Health Association at its 55th meeting held in Buffalo, N.Y., on
October 11, 1926, and approved by the Governing Council of the Association
on October 14, 1926. The above report begins by defining the terms generally
used to avoid possible errors or misinterpretations; each disease is briefly
described in relation to its infectious agent; the source of infection; the
mode of transmission; the period of incubation and of communicability; then
control methods are given both for the individual and his environment and
finally the general measures for the prevention of the diseases. Well, then,
in that article, which is officially approved by the Public Health Service
of the United States, the following statement occurs under yellow fever
which I have translated:
1.- Infectious agent - Unknown
6.- Methods of control
3.- Immunization - None.

This does not need any comment, and with it I have answered the
last statement which we refute.

Now, then, there is only one logical conclusion to be drawn from
all that has been said above! The person is guilty either of gross ignor-
ance or of a manifest determination to usurp the glory of the greatest man
that America has produced in the medical field during the last half century.
- 20 -
If the former is the case, it must be agreed that that ignorance is in-
excusable by those who hold a high position in the scientific world. If
the latter is the case, the entire weight of the blame by the man who
loves truth and justice must fall on them.
